diseases.name: App (Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae)
diseases.transmission: Aerosol transmission over short distances (not long-range). Survives outside pig only few days. Introduced via carrier pigs. Stress and coinfections (PRRS, influenza) trigger clinical disease. Does not survive well in environment.
diseases.description: Pleuropneumonia caused by Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae with at least 15 serotypes (1,2,5,9,11 most virulent; 3,7 mild). Bacteria carried in tonsils/upper respiratory tract. Incubation 3-12 hours. Toxin production causes severe pulmonary damage. Affects 8-16 week old pigs typically. Can remain subclinical in carriers for months.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: sudden death + nasal hemorrhage + respiratory distress. Post-mortem: pleuropneumonia with fibrinous pleuritis. Laboratory: bacterial isolation from lung/pleural fluid, PCR, serology (ELISA). Serotyping important for vaccine selection.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination with serotype-specific or cross-protective vaccines. Select App-negative replacement stock. Strategic medication during high-risk periods. All-in/all-out management. In outbreaks: examine groups 3x daily. Reduce stress and optimize ventilation.
diseases.treatment: Immediate mass injection of entire at-risk group (dont wait for individual identification). Broad-spectrum antibiotics: ceftiofur, florfenicol, tulathromycin, enrofloxacin. Injectable route essential (sick pigs stop eating/drinking). Continue treatment 3-5 days. Early intervention critical for survival.

diseases.name: Campylobacter infection
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral transmission. Environmental contamination from infected animals. Can be part of normal gut flora. Spread through contaminated water and feed.
diseases.description: Usually subclinical infection caused by Campylobacter coli and C. jejuni. Mainly affects young piglets causing mild diarrhea. Generally self-limiting with little economic impact. Part of normal intestinal flora in many pigs.
diseases.diagnosis: Usually diagnosed retrospectively. Fecal culture on selective media. PCR available. Dark-field microscopy shows characteristic darting motility. Clinical significance often uncertain.
diseases.controlPrevention: Good hygiene and sanitation practices. Proper cleaning and disinfection between batches. Maintain clean water supply. Usually no specific control needed due to low pathogenicity.
diseases.treatment: Usually self-limiting and treatment unnecessary. If needed: erythromycin, tylosin, or lincomycin. Supportive care with electrolytes if dehydrated. Antibiotics rarely justified.

diseases.name: Clostridium difficile
diseases.transmission: Environmental contamination with spores. Fecal-oral transmission. Spores very resistant and persist in facilities. Activated by gut conditions in neonates. Associated with antibiotic use disrupting normal flora.
diseases.description: Anaerobic spore-forming bacterium causing neonatal diarrhea in piglets within first hours to days of life. Produces toxins A and B causing intestinal damage. Spores persist in environment making control difficult.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: neonatal diarrhea in first days of life. Laboratory: detection of toxins A/B in feces by ELISA or PCR. Culture on selective media. Differentiate from other neonatal diarrheas (E. coli, Clostridium perfringens).
diseases.controlPrevention: Difficult due to environmental spore persistence. Thorough cleaning and disinfection (though spores resist many disinfectants). Improve farrowing house hygiene. Ensure adequate colostrum intake. Avoid unnecessary antibiotics.
diseases.treatment: Metronidazole or vancomycin orally. Supportive fluid therapy for dehydration. Early treatment important. Probiotic supplementation may help restore gut flora.

diseases.name: Clostridium novyi
diseases.transmission: Spores in environment (soil, feces). Enter through wounds (castration, tail docking, fighting, injections). Anaerobic conditions in damaged tissue allow germination and toxin production.
diseases.description: Anaerobic spore-forming bacterium causing sudden death with gangrenous cellulitis. Organism enters through wounds and produces potent toxins. Relatively uncommon but rapidly fatal. Spores persist in soil and environment.
diseases.diagnosis: Often diagnosed post-mortem: characteristic gangrenous lesions, gas in tissues, dark discoloration. Fluorescent antibody test on tissue. Anaerobic culture from affected tissues. PCR available.
diseases.controlPrevention: Minimize wounds and trauma. Proper hygiene during processing (castration, tail docking). Clean injection equipment. Environmental sanitation. Vaccination where disease is endemic.
diseases.treatment: Usually too rapid for treatment. High-dose penicillin if caught early. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. Supportive care. Prevention is key.

diseases.name: Clostridium perfringens
diseases.transmission: Environmental spores ubiquitous in soil and feces. Fecal-oral transmission. Multiplication in gut when conditions favor (diet changes, stress). Type C more common in piglets 1-3 days old.
diseases.description: Anaerobic spore-forming bacterium causing acute necrotizing enteritis in piglets. Type C most common (beta toxin). Type A also causes disease. Can also cause gangrenous cellulitis. Environmental spores widespread.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: hemorrhagic enteritis in young piglets. Post-mortem: necrotic enteritis, especially jejunum/ileum. Laboratory: detection of toxins in intestinal contents by ELISA/PCR. Culture from fresh intestine.
diseases.controlPrevention: Sow vaccination (Type C toxoid) provides passive immunity via colostrum. Good farrowing hygiene. Ensure adequate colostrum intake. Strategic use of antibiotics in feed. Reduce stress.
diseases.treatment: High-dose penicillin or amoxicillin. Antitoxin (if available) early in disease. Supportive fluid therapy. Often too rapid for successful treatment. Focus on prevention.

diseases.name: Mycoplasma suis (Eperythrozoonosis)
diseases.transmission: Blood transmission via contaminated needles (most common), lice infestation (Haematopinus suis), biting flies, tail biting/wounds, can cross placenta. Widespread in pig populations.
diseases.description: Hemotropic mycoplasma (formerly Eperythrozoon suis) infecting red blood cells causing anemia. Can cross placenta. Clinical disease more common in lactating sows and growing pigs. Subclinical infection widespread.
diseases.diagnosis: Blood smear with Wright or Giemsa stain (less sensitive). PCR most reliable. Serology improving. Presence of organism doesnt confirm clinical disease (many carriers). Check for anemia (low PCV/hemoglobin).
diseases.controlPrevention: Single-use needles or proper sterilization. Control lice with insecticides. Minimize wounds and tail biting. Avoid unnecessary blood-letting procedures. Test and eliminate carriers.
diseases.treatment: Tetracyclines (oxytetracycline, doxycycline) very effective. Injectable or in-feed. Treatment 5-10 days. Iron supplementation if anemic. Treat secondary infections. Response usually good if caught early.

diseases.name: Actinobacillosis
diseases.transmission: Opportunistic pathogen entering through wounds, tonsils, or respiratory tract. Environmental contamination. Spread by direct contact and aerosols. Stress and poor immunity predispose.
diseases.description: Systemic infection caused by Actinobacillus suis (different from App). Affects farms with health issues. Causes multiple clinical syndromes: septicemia, arthritis, pneumonia, skin lesions. More common in poor health status herds.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs with skin lesions characteristic. Post-mortem: septicemia, pneumonia, arthritis. Laboratory: bacterial culture from affected tissues, blood. PCR. Differentiate from App (A. pleuropneumoniae).
diseases.controlPrevention: Improve herd health status. Minimize wounds and stress. Good hygiene and management. Proper ventilation. Strategic medication during high-risk periods. All-in/all-out.
diseases.treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics: penicillin, ceftiofur, amoxicillin. Injectable initially then in-feed. NSAIDs for pain/fever. Drainage of abscesses if present. Prolonged treatment may be needed.

diseases.name: Anthrax
diseases.transmission: Spores in soil (can persist decades). Ingestion of contaminated feed/soil. Inhalation less common. Carcass contamination spreads spores. Endemic in certain geographic areas.
diseases.description: Rare in pigs but acute fatal disease caused by Bacillus anthracis spores from soil. Three forms: pharyngeal (most common in pigs), intestinal, systemic septicemia. **Highly zoonotic - human safety critical**. Notifiable disease.
diseases.diagnosis: **Do NOT perform necropsy in field** - spreads spores. Diagnosis by blood smear (square-ended rods in chains), culture from blood, PCR, antigen detection. Report immediately to authorities.
diseases.controlPrevention: **Immediate quarantine and authority notification**. Carcass disposal by burning or deep burial with quicklime (never open). Vaccination in endemic areas (protective). Environmental decontamination very difficult.
diseases.treatment: High-dose penicillin if caught very early (usually too late). **Human exposure requires immediate medical attention**. Focus on rapid diagnosis, containment, and reporting.

diseases.name: Atrophic Rhinitis
diseases.transmission: Aerosol transmission from carrier sows to piglets. B. bronchiseptica colonizes first, followed by P. multocida. Damage cumulative from 2-12 weeks. Maternal immunity wanes by 3-4 weeks.
diseases.description: Progressive atrophy of nasal turbinate bones caused by Bordetella bronchiseptica and toxigenic Pasteurella multocida type D. Leads to nasal deformity (shortened/twisted snout). Mainly affects growing pigs. Sows are carriers.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: snout deformity in growing pigs. Post-mortem: turbinate atrophy (score 0-5). Bacterial culture from nasal swabs. Serology for P. multocida toxin antibodies in sows.
diseases.controlPrevention: Sow vaccination (P. multocida toxoid + B. bronchiseptica bacterin) before farrowing. Piglet vaccination at 1 and 3-4 weeks. Strategic antibiotics. Depopulation-repopulation in severe cases.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics in early stages: sulfonamides, tetracyclines, ceftiofur in water/feed. Once turbinate damage occurs, irreversible. Prevention through vaccination most effective.

diseases.name: Bordetellosis (Bordetella bronchiseptica)
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious aerosol transmission. Sow-to-piglet at farrowing. Persists in tonsils. Environmental survival limited. Present in most herds.
diseases.description: Primary colonizer of respiratory tract. Alone causes mild disease, but potentiates other pathogens (PRRS, influenza). Essential component of atrophic rhinitis (with P. multocida). Widespread in pig populations.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs usually mild. Bacterial culture from nasal swabs or lung tissue. PCR available. Serology shows widespread exposure. Often diagnosed as part of respiratory complex.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination as part of atrophic rhinitis prevention. Improve air quality and reduce stress. Control other respiratory pathogens. Strategic antibiotics.
diseases.treatment: Responds to many antibiotics: tetracyclines, penicillins, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones. Usually treat in combination with other respiratory diseases.

diseases.name: Botulism
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of toxin in contaminated feed, spoiled silage, or decomposing carcasses (dead animals in feed). Spores widespread in environment but toxin only produced in anaerobic conditions.
diseases.description: Rare intoxication caused by neurotoxins of Clostridium botulinum. Pigs relatively resistant compared to other species. Results from ingestion of preformed toxin in spoiled feed/carcasses. Progressive flaccid paralysis.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: progressive flaccid paralysis with normal temperature/consciousness. Mouse bioassay for toxin detection. Rule out other causes of paralysis (Aujeszky, salt poisoning).
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed quality control. Proper carcass disposal. Prevent access to decomposing material. Remove spoiled feed immediately. Vaccination available but rarely used.
diseases.treatment: Antitoxin if available and diagnosed early (expensive, rarely available for pigs). Supportive care. Prognosis guarded to poor. Most cases fatal.

diseases.name: Brucellosis
diseases.transmission: Venereal transmission (natural mating or AI), direct contact with aborted material, ingestion of contaminated feed/water. Can persist in tissues for months.
diseases.description: Caused by Brucella suis (biovars 1-3). Chronic reproductive disease with **zoonotic importance**. Mainly affects breeding animals. Notifiable in many countries. Can cause severe human disease.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology (SAT, ELISA, CFT). Bacterial culture from aborted fetuses, semen, lymph nodes. PCR. Test boars and breeding stock. **Human exposure risk during sampling/necropsy**.
diseases.controlPrevention: Test and cull program. Do not introduce animals from infected herds. Artificial insemination with tested boars. Quarantine and test new stock. Vaccination not available in most countries.
diseases.treatment: No practical treatment (organism intracellular). Cull infected animals. Long-term antibiotics (doxycycline + rifampin) attempted but not economic. Focus on eradication.

diseases.name: Colibacillosis (E. coli diarrhea)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral route. Environmental contamination. Sow carriers shed at farrowing. Poor hygiene, cold/damp conditions, inadequate colostrum, overcrowding, stress all predispose. Certain strains produce enterotoxins (LT, ST).
diseases.description: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) with fimbrial adhesins (F4/K88, F5/K99, F6/987P, F18, F41) causing diarrhea. Neonatal (0-4 days), post-weaning (7-14 days post-weaning), and edema disease forms. Leading cause of piglet diarrhea.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + age + profuse diarrhea. Bacterial culture from fresh feces/intestine identifying pathogenic E. coli. Virulence factor detection (PCR for toxins and adhesins). Antimicrobial susceptibility testing essential.
diseases.controlPrevention: Sow vaccination (F4/F18 bacterins) before farrowing provides passive immunity. Adequate colostrum (within 6 hours). Warm, dry, clean farrowing environment. Gradual diet changes at weaning. Hygiene critical.
diseases.treatment: Fluid/electrolyte therapy essential. Antibiotics based on susceptibility: enrofloxacin, apramycin, colistin, neomycin. Oral preferred for enteric form. Zinc oxide in feed at weaning. Probiotic/prebiotic supplementation.

diseases.name: Colitis (Spirochetal colitis)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral transmission. Contaminated environment. Carrier pigs. Stress factors precipitate clinical disease. Does not survive well outside host.
diseases.description: Infection of large intestine by spirochetes (Brachyspira pilosicoli, less pathogenic than B. hyodysenteriae). Affects 6-14 week old pigs. Causes mucoid diarrhea without blood. Less severe than swine dysentery.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: diarrhea without blood in 6-14 week pigs. Fecal PCR for B. pilosicoli. Culture on selective media. Histopathology: spirochetes adhering to colonic mucosa. Differentiate from swine dysentery.
diseases.controlPrevention: All-in/all-out management. Thorough cleaning between groups. Reduce stocking density. Control other enteric pathogens. Strategic medication in feed.
diseases.treatment: Antibiotics: tiamulin, valnemulin, lincomycin, tylosin in feed/water. Usually good response. Less resistance than swine dysentery. 7-14 day treatment course.

diseases.name: Edema disease
diseases.transmission: E. coli F18 colonization in small intestine. Shiga toxin (Stx2e) production. Diet changes and weaning stress trigger. Rapid feed intake of high-protein diet predisposes. Genetic susceptibility exists.
diseases.description: Post-weaning E. coli disease caused by Shiga toxin-producing F18 strains. Occurs 1-2 weeks post-weaning in fast-growing pigs. Toxin damages blood vessel walls causing edema and neurological signs. Often fatal.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: sudden death or CNS signs + eyelid edema in recently weaned pigs. Post-mortem: edema of stomach wall, mesocolon, eyelids. Bacterial culture + toxin gene detection (PCR). Histopathology: vascular damage.
diseases.controlPrevention: Gradual weaning transition. Lower protein initially. Feed restriction first few days. Acidify feed/water. Select for F18 resistance genetically. Vaccination (limited efficacy). Avoid sudden diet changes.
diseases.treatment: Often too late (sudden death). Antibiotics if caught early: apramycin, colistin, neomycin. Reduce feed intake. Supportive care. Corticosteroids may reduce edema. Prevention key strategy.

diseases.name: Enzootic Pneumonia (EP) - Mycoplasma hyopneumoniae
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious via aerosol over short distances. Direct nose-to-nose contact. Sow-to-piglet transmission. Very slow spreading (long generation time). Survives poorly outside host.
diseases.description: Chronic progressive pneumonia caused by M. hyopneumoniae. Most economically significant respiratory disease globally. Slow spread within herd (5-10% per week). Potentiates secondary infections (PRRS, APP, Pasteurella). Present in most herds.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: chronic cough in growing pigs. Post-mortem: cranioventral lung consolidation (purple-gray). Serology (ELISA). PCR on BAL or lung tissue. Gross lung scoring at slaughter monitoring.
diseases.controlPrevention: Eradication possible (medicated early weaning, test/removal, depopulation-repopulation). Vaccination highly effective (reduces lung lesions 50-75%). Improve air quality. All-in/all-out. Minimize mixing.
diseases.treatment: Macrolides (tulathromycin, tiamulin, tylvalosin, tilmicosin) most effective. Tetracyclines also used. Strategic medication (pulse dosing). Usually in-feed. Treatment reduces clinical signs but doesnt eliminate infection.

diseases.name: Erysipelas (Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae)
diseases.transmission: Ubiquitous in environment (soil, feces). Enters via wounds, tonsils, GI tract. Carrier pigs. Stress triggers clinical disease. Skin abrasions facilitate entry. Survives well in organic matter.
diseases.description: Three clinical forms: 1) Acute (septicemia, diamond skin), 2) Subacute (diamond skin lesions), 3) Chronic (arthritis, endocarditis). Organism widespread in environment (soil). Survives months outside host. Important economic disease.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: diamond-shaped skin lesions highly suggestive. Post-mortem: splenomegaly, kidney lesions, vegetative endocarditis in chronic. Bacterial culture from blood/tissues. PCR. Fluorescent antibody test.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination highly effective (bacterins or attenuated vaccines). Vaccinate breeding stock 2x yearly. Growing pigs once. Minimize skin trauma. Good hygiene. Prompt treatment of outbreaks.
diseases.treatment: Penicillin extremely effective (drug of choice). Response within 24-48 hours. Single dose often sufficient. Alternative: ceftiofur, lincomycin. Chronic arthritis/endocarditis may not respond. NSAIDs for pain.

diseases.name: Exudative Epidermitis (Greasy Pig Disease)
diseases.transmission: S. hyicus colonizes skin. Entry through wounds, abrasions, mange lesions, fighting, rough flooring. Bacterial toxin causes skin damage. Stress and poor hygiene predispose.
diseases.description: Staphylococcus hyicus skin infection. Produces exfoliative toxins causing epidermis separation. Affects piglets 3 days to 8 weeks. Enters through skin abrasions (fighting, rough surfaces, mange). Can be rapidly fatal.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs highly characteristic: greasy brown skin exudate. Bacterial culture from skin lesions. Histopathology: epidermal necrosis and separation. Rule out mange (skin scraping).
diseases.controlPrevention: Minimize skin trauma: smooth surfaces, trim needle teeth carefully, control mange, reduce fighting. Hygiene critical. Prompt treatment of mange. Sow vaccination has limited efficacy.
diseases.treatment: Systemic antibiotics essential: penicillin, amoxicillin, ceftiofur, lincomycin. Topical antiseptics (chlorhexidine). Rehydration therapy. Isolate affected pigs. Early treatment critical - mortality high if delayed.

diseases.name: Glässer disease (Glaesserella parasuis)
diseases.transmission: Resident in upper respiratory tract. Aerosol transmission. Stress (weaning, mixing, transport, other diseases) triggers invasion. Loss of maternal immunity at 3-5 weeks. Virulent strains cause more disease.
diseases.description: Polyserositis and arthritis caused by G. parasuis (15 serotypes, varying virulence). Present in most herds. Clinical disease when maternal immunity wanes (3-8 weeks) or stress occurs. Secondary to PRRS, influenza. High mortality without treatment.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs in 3-8 week pigs: sudden death/meningitis/polyserositis. Post-mortem: fibrinous inflammation of pleura, pericardium, peritoneum, joints. Bacterial culture from affected sites. PCR. Serology limited value.
diseases.controlPrevention: Reduce stress at weaning. Minimize mixing. Control primary pathogens (PRRS, influenza). Vaccination (autogenous or commercial for prevalent serotypes). All-in/all-out. Good air quality.
diseases.treatment: Highly antibiotic-sensitive initially: penicillin, ampicillin, ceftiofur, florfenicol, enrofloxacin. Must treat EARLY (resistance develops during infection). Injectable then in-feed. Treat entire group. 5-7 day course minimum.

diseases.name: Ileitis (Lawsonia intracellularis)
diseases.transmission: Intracellular bacterium in intestinal epithelium. Fecal-oral transmission. Subclinical carriers. Stress triggers clinical disease. Survives in environment (water, feces). Contaminated facilities.
diseases.description: Three forms: 1) Porcine Intestinal Adenopathy (PIA) - chronic proliferative, 2) Necrotic Enteritis (NE) - gross thickening, 3) Proliferative Hemorrhagic Enteropathy (PHE) - acute bloody. Most common in 6-20 week pigs. Major economic impact.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + age (6-20 weeks). Fecal PCR (shedding intermittent). Serology (IgG antibodies 3 weeks post-infection). Post-mortem: thickened intestinal mucosa (hosepipe gut), hemorrhage in PHE. IHC on intestinal tissue.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (attenuated live oral vaccine) highly effective. Strategic medication at high-risk periods. All-in/all-out. Reduce stocking density. Control other stressors. Treat water systems.
diseases.treatment: Macrolides most effective: tylosin, tylvalosin, tiamulin, valnemulin. Tetracyclines also used. In-feed medication for 3-4 weeks. Individual treatment for PHE: injectable tulathromycin. Resistance developing in some areas.

diseases.name: Leptospirosis
diseases.transmission: Urine contamination (main route). Contaminated water. Venereal transmission. Transplacental to fetuses. Rats and wildlife reservoirs. Survives in warm moist environment. Enters via mucous membranes.
diseases.description: Leptospira interrogans (multiple serovars). Chronic reproductive disease. Zoonotic. Organism persists in kidney, shed in urine. Carrier pigs important. Wild animals (rats, wildlife) reservoirs.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology (MAT - microscopic agglutination test) for antibody detection. PCR on aborted fetuses, urine. Bacterial culture difficult. Paired serology shows rising titers. IFA on kidney tissue post-mortem.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination recommended in endemic areas. Rodent control critical. Prevent urine contamination of water/feed. Quarantine and test new stock. Drain wet areas. Wear gloves when handling urine/tissues.
diseases.treatment: Streptomycin or dihydrostreptomycin most effective. Tetracyclines also used. Treat breeding herd in outbreaks. Long-acting formulations available. May not eliminate kidney carriers.

diseases.name: Listeriosis
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of contaminated feed (especially poor-quality silage, pH>5). Environmental contamination. Fecal shedding by carriers. Can multiply at refrigeration temperatures. **Human risk from handling**.
diseases.description: Listeria monocytogenes. Rare in pigs. Three forms: septicemia (young pigs), encephalitis (nervous signs), reproductive (abortions). Environmental organism (silage, soil, feces). **Zoonotic - serious human pathogen**.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + compatible history (silage feeding). Bacterial culture from brain, aborted fetus, septicemic tissues. PCR available. CSF culture in meningitis. **Biosafety important - inform lab**.
diseases.controlPrevention: Improve feed quality (proper silage fermentation). Avoid feeding spoiled/moldy feed. Discard silage with pH>5. Environmental sanitation. Vaccination not available.
diseases.treatment: High-dose penicillin, ampicillin, or tetracyclines. Prolonged treatment (2-3 weeks). Often poor response in CNS cases. Prevention through feed quality critical.

diseases.name: Mycoplasma arthritis
diseases.transmission: Aerosol/oro-nasal transmission. M. hyosynoviae colonizes tonsils. Stress triggers joint invasion. M. hyorhinis associated with pneumonia/serositis. Mixing and transport common triggers.
diseases.description: M. hyosynoviae (most important) and M. hyorhinis cause polyarthritis. M. hyosynoviae sudden lameness in growing pigs. M. hyorhinis younger pigs, often with serositis. Both widespread.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: sudden lameness in growing pigs. Synovial fluid: turbid, increased WBC. PCR on synovial fluid. Bacterial culture difficult (fastidious). Serology shows herd exposure.
diseases.controlPrevention: Reduce stress (avoid mixing, transport during outbreaks). All-in/all-out. Good nutrition. Vaccination (autogenous) limited success. Minimize concurrent diseases.
diseases.treatment: Lincomycin most effective (IV or IM initially, then in-feed). Tetracyclines (especially doxycycline). Tiamulin. Tylosin. Early treatment important (joint damage becomes irreversible). NSAIDs for pain. 7-14 day course.

diseases.name: Pasteurellosis (Pasteurella multocida)
diseases.transmission: Resident in upper respiratory tract. Aerosol transmission. Secondary invader after primary viral/mycoplasma damage. Stress and poor air quality predispose. Toxigenic strains damage turbinates.
diseases.description: P. multocida usually secondary pathogen in respiratory disease complex (after PRRS, influenza, M. hyopneumoniae). Also component of atrophic rhinitis (toxigenic Type D). Opportunistic pathogen in compromised lungs.
diseases.diagnosis: Usually diagnosed as part of respiratory complex. Bacterial culture from lung lesions. PCR. Toxin gene detection for AR-associated strains. Post-mortem: cranioventral pneumonia with pleuritis.
diseases.controlPrevention: Control primary pathogens (PRRS, influenza, M. hyopneumoniae). Improve ventilation. Reduce stocking density. Vaccination for AR prevention. Strategic antibiotics at high-risk times.
diseases.treatment: Sensitive to many antibiotics: penicillins, cephalosporins (ceftiofur), florfenicol, macrolides, tetracyclines. Injectable or in-feed depending on severity. Usually 5-7 day course.

diseases.name: Postpartum Agalactia Syndrome (MMA)
diseases.transmission: E. coli/bacterial invasion from environment, poor hygiene, constipation, obesity, stress, poor body condition, genetic predisposition. Build-up from previous litters.
diseases.description: Multifactorial: Mastitis-Metritis-Agalactia. E. coli, Klebsiella, Staph most common. Inflammatory response reduces milk. Major cause of pre-weaning mortality through starvation. Occurs within 48h post-farrowing.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs within 48h post-farrowing. Rectal temperature >39.5°C. Udder palpation: firm, hot, painful. Bacterial culture from milk/vaginal discharge. Piglet weights declining.
diseases.controlPrevention: Farrowing house hygiene critical. Adequate fiber in gestation diet. Avoid excessive body condition. Exercise. Clean udder before farrowing. Oxytocin at farrowing. Adequate water access.
diseases.treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics (amoxicillin, ceftiofur). Oxytocin for milk letdown (2-3x daily for 2 days). NSAIDs for fever/pain. Prostaglandins may help uterine discharge. Treat constipation. Assist piglets to nurse or cross-foster.

diseases.name: Salmonellosis
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral transmission. Contaminated feed (especially animal proteins). Environmental persistence. Carrier pigs shed intermittently. Rodent vectors. Stress activates shedding. Biofilm formation in water systems.
diseases.description: Multiple Salmonella serovars. Three presentations: 1) Enteric (diarrhea), 2) Septicemic (acute death), 3) Respiratory (pneumonia). Carrier pigs major reservoir. Feed contamination important. **Zoonotic - major food safety concern**.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + epidemiology. Bacterial culture from feces, tissues, feed. Serology for herd monitoring. PCR. Post-mortem: button ulcers in colon, splenomegaly, pneumonia. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing essential.
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed biosecurity (heat treatment, acids). Rodent/fly control. Hygiene. Stress reduction. Acidified water. Probiotics/prebiotics. Competitive exclusion products. Vaccination (limited efficacy). Slaughter hygiene critical.
diseases.treatment: Fluoroquinolones (enrofloxacin, marbofloxacin) very effective. Ceftiofur. Trimethoprim-sulfa. In-feed apramycin, colistin. **Antibiotic resistance concern** - use judiciously. Supportive fluid therapy. May not eliminate carriers.

diseases.name: Streptococcal infections
diseases.transmission: Colonizes upper respiratory tract. Stress/immunosuppression triggers invasion. Enters via wounds, respiratory tract. Piglet infection from sows. Mixing, transport, other diseases predispose. **Human infection via wounds**.
diseases.description: Streptococcus suis (35 serotypes, type 2 most important). Three forms: 1) Septicemia (sudden death), 2) Meningitis (CNS signs), 3) Arthritis. Colonizes tonsils/respiratory tract. **Zoonotic - serious in humans**.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: sudden death or CNS signs in weaners/growers. CSF: turbid, increased protein/WBC. Bacterial culture from CSF, blood, joints, brain. PCR. Serology. **Lab safety - zoonotic**.
diseases.controlPrevention: Reduce stress and mixing. All-in/all-out. Improve air quality. Minimize nose-ringing. Control primary pathogens (PRRS, influenza). Vaccination (autogenous for prevalent serotypes). **Workers use PPE**.
diseases.treatment: Penicillin, ampicillin, ceftiofur most effective. Treat early (CNS damage irreversible). High doses for CNS penetration. Injectable initially, then in-feed for groups. 7-10 days. NSAIDs. Resistance emerging.

diseases.name: Swine dysentery (Brachyspira hyodysenteriae)
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious fecal-oral. Survives in feces 48 days, longer in cold wet conditions. Carriers (recovered pigs). Rodents may carry. Contaminated boots/vehicles. Feed/water contamination.
diseases.description: Severe mucohemorrhagic colitis caused by B. hyodysenteriae. Highly contagious. Major economic impact. Primarily affects growing-finishing pigs (8-14 weeks). Can be eradicated but easily reintroduced.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: bloody mucoid diarrhea in growers. Fresh fecal PCR (gold standard). Culture on selective media (fastidious). Histopathology: spirochetes in colonic crypts. Rule out salmonellosis, ileitis.
diseases.controlPrevention: Eradication possible: depopulation, thorough C&D, strategic medication. Control: all-in/all-out, strict biosecurity, dry conditions, rodent control. Prevent introduction via carriers.
diseases.treatment: Tiamulin (most effective), valnemulin, lincomycin in water/feed. Combination therapy (tiamulin + doxycycline) reduces resistance. 10-14 days. **Antimicrobial resistance increasing**. Tylosin ineffective.

diseases.name: Tetanus (Clostridium tetani)
diseases.transmission: Spores ubiquitous in soil/feces. Enter via wounds (castration, tail docking, injections, foot lesions). Anaerobic conditions in wounds allow germination and toxin production.
diseases.description: Neurotoxin disease from C. tetani spores in wounds. Rare in pigs but classic presentation when occurs. Toxin blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters causing muscle rigidity. Usually sporadic individual cases.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs highly characteristic: muscle rigidity + hypersensitivity + normal temperature. History of recent wound. Diagnosis clinical. Confirm by ruling out other causes of rigidity.
diseases.controlPrevention: Minimize wounds. Aseptic technique for processing. Wound management. Vaccination (toxoid) rarely done in pigs but effective. Environmental sanitation difficult (spores persist).
diseases.treatment: Antitoxin if early (neutralizes unbound toxin). High-dose penicillin. Muscle relaxants (diazepam). Quiet, dark environment (reduce stimulation). Supportive nutrition/hydration. Prognosis guarded.

diseases.name: Tuberculosis (Mycobacterium avium complex)
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of M. avium from environment (soil, water, birds). Fecal shedding by infected birds. Lesions develop slowly over months. Outdoor pigs higher risk.
diseases.description: Rare today. M. avium complex most common in pigs. Chronic granulomatous lymphadenitis. Economic loss from carcass condemnation at slaughter (cervical lymph nodes). Human infection unlikely from pigs.
diseases.diagnosis: Usually detected at slaughter (granulomas in lymph nodes, especially head/neck). Histopathology: acid-fast bacteria, granulomas. Culture (slow, weeks). PCR. Tuberculin testing not reliable in pigs.
diseases.controlPrevention: Indoor confinement reduces exposure. Avoid bird contact. Clean water supply. Stamping out if detected. Test and cull programs rare (economics). SPF herds maintained TB-free.
diseases.treatment: No practical treatment (chronic granulomatous). Cull infected animals. Not economic to treat. Focus on prevention through herd management.

diseases.name: Yersinia infection
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral transmission. Environmental contamination. Carrier pigs important. Cold-growing organism (multiplies at refrigeration). **Human infection from contaminated pork**.
diseases.description: Y. enterocolitica and Y. pseudotuberculosis. Usually subclinical carriage. Occasionally causes diarrhea in weaners. **Zoonotic importance** - pork source of human infection.
diseases.diagnosis: Usually incidental finding. Culture from feces, lymph nodes. PCR. Serology. Post-mortem: enlarged ileocecal lymph nodes with micro-abscesses.
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene and biosecurity. **Slaughter hygiene critical for food safety**. Proper cooking of pork. Carrier status common, eradication difficult.
diseases.treatment: Usually unnecessary (subclinical). If needed: tetracyclines, trimethoprim-sulfa, fluoroquinolones. Focus on food safety measures rather than treatment.

diseases.name: African Swine Fever (ASF)
diseases.transmission: **Main route globally: contaminated pork products in swill**. Direct contact with infected pigs/wild boar. Soft tick bite (Africa). Fomites (boots, vehicles, equipment). Semen. Virus survives 100+ days in chilled meat, 3 years in frozen, months in blood, 11 days in feces.
diseases.description: **Most important swine disease globally**. Asfivirus. No vaccine or treatment. Mortality up to 100%. Multiple strains (22 genotypes). Soft ticks (Ornithodoros) reservoir in Africa. Virus extremely stable in meat/environment. **Notifiable OIE disease**.
diseases.diagnosis: **Immediately notify authorities - suspect diagnosis reportable**. Clinical signs + epidemiology. Laboratory: PCR (gold standard), virus isolation, antigen detection, serology (ELISA, IFT), hemadsorption test. **MUST differentiate from CSF**. Post-mortem: hemorrhages, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy.
diseases.controlPrevention: **NO VACCINE - eradication only through stamping out**. Strict biosecurity: ban swill feeding, control wild boar contact, quarantine imports, disinfect vehicles, footbaths, change clothes/boots. Early detection critical. Zoning and movement restrictions. Dispose carcasses safely (burn/bury deep).
diseases.treatment: NO TREATMENT. **Infected herds must be culled (stamped out)**. Quarantine 3km radius. Trace contacts. Environmental decontamination (alkali cleaners, hypochlorite). Premises empty 40 days minimum. Surveillance 12-18 months.

diseases.name: Aujeszky's disease (Pseudorabies, PRV)
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious aerosol (2-10km range). Direct contact. Contaminated semen. Wild boar reservoir (major problem in endemic areas). Vertical transmission to fetuses. Fomites. Mechanical vectors (humans, vehicles). Reactivation of latent infection under stress.
diseases.description: Herpesvirus (Suid herpesvirus 1). **Major global disease**. Remains latent in trigeminal ganglia lifelong. Reactivation under stress. Crosses placenta. **Fatal in other species** (dogs, cats, cattle). Aerosol spread 2-10km. Many countries have eradication programs.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + age-related severity. Laboratory: virus isolation from brain/tonsils, PCR, serology (ELISA, VN test, gB/gE ELISA to differentiate vaccine vs field strains). CSF in CNS cases. **Must differentiate field virus from vaccine strains** for eradication programs.
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination effective (gene-deleted vaccines allow DIVA testing). Eradication programs: test and removal of positive animals, strict biosecurity, depopulation-repopulation. Wild boar control critical. Quarantine new stock. Prevent nose-to-nose contact with wildlife.
diseases.treatment: NO TREATMENT (virus latent lifelong). Supportive care for secondary infections. Focus on prevention through vaccination or eradication. **Do not use live vaccines in eradication programs**. Many countries/regions now PRV-free.

diseases.name: PRRS (Porcine Reproductive & Respiratory Syndrome)
diseases.transmission: Aerosol transmission (documented up to 9km with right conditions). Direct contact. Contaminated semen (AI critical). Fomites (needles, boots, vehicles). Transplacental to fetuses. Fecal-oral. Nasal secretions, saliva, urine. Virus labile (short survival outside host).
diseases.description: **Highest economic impact respiratory/reproductive disease in North America and Europe**. Arterivirus. Two types: PRRSV-1 (European/Lelystad) and PRRSV-2 (North American, generally more virulent). Highly mutable. Destroys alveolar macrophages (40% loss). Can become endemic.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + epidemiology. Serology (ELISA - herd screening). PCR on serum, tissue, oral fluids (preferred for monitoring). Virus isolation. Sequencing for outbreak investigation. IHC on tissues. **Oral fluid PCR revolutionized monitoring** (pen-based sampling).
diseases.controlPrevention: Biosecurity critical: shower-in facilities, downtime for vehicles, quarantine gilt acclimation, AI from PRRSnegative boars, air filtration (expensive but effective), minimizing outside contacts. Modified live vaccines (homologous protection best, heterologous variable). Regional control programs. Consider herd closure + rollover.
diseases.treatment: NO antiviral treatment. Antibiotics for secondary bacterial infections (ceftiofur, tulathromycin, florfenicol for respiratory). NSAIDs for fever. Supportive care. Strategic herd closure (stop gilt introduction 200 days) allows stabilization. Some farms pursue elimination through test/removal.

diseases.name: Blue eye disease
diseases.transmission: Direct contact, aerosol, very contagious within herds
diseases.description: Paramyxovirus causing corneal opacity (blue eye), nervous signs, reproductive failure. Found in Mexico, South America. Young pigs most affected.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (blue eyes characteristic), virus isolation, serology, PCR
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination in endemic areas, biosecurity, no introduction from affected regions
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment, supportive care, control secondary infections

diseases.name: BVDV
diseases.transmission: Contact with infected cattle, contaminated biologicals
diseases.description: Bovine viral diarrhea pestiviruses (BVDV-1, BVDV-2) occasionally infect pigs. Mainly reproductive problems in sows. Rare.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology (cross-reacts with CSF), virus isolation, PCR. Rule out CSF
diseases.controlPrevention: Avoid cattle contact, biosecurity, test biological products
diseases.treatment: No treatment, supportive care

diseases.name: Classical Swine Fever (CSF, Hog Cholera)
diseases.transmission: Direct contact, contaminated meat products, fomites, semen. Long survival in frozen meat
diseases.description: Pestivirus. **OIE notifiable**. Very similar to ASF clinically. Acute/chronic/congenital forms. Some countries vaccine-free (eradication), others endemic with vaccination.
diseases.diagnosis: **Report immediately**. Clinical signs, PCR, virus isolation, antigen ELISA, antibody ELISA (differentiate from BVDV), IHC
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccine-free countries: stamping out. Endemic areas: vaccination (C-strain, marker vaccines for DIVA). Ban swill, import controls
diseases.treatment: NO TREATMENT. Stamp out in free countries. Vaccination in endemic regions

diseases.name: Delta coronavirus (PDCoV)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, contaminated feed (suspected)
diseases.description: Recently emerged coronavirus causing mild diarrhea similar to PED but lower severity. Affects young pigs mainly. Widespread but low impact.
diseases.diagnosis: PCR on feces/intestinal tissue. Differentiate from PED, TGE, rotavirus
diseases.controlPrevention: Biosecurity, hygiene. Lower priority than PED/TGE
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment, supportive care, maintain hydration

diseases.name: Ebola Reston virus
diseases.transmission: Unknown in pigs. Contact suspected
diseases.description: Ebola Reston strain infects pigs (other Ebola strains do not). Usually asymptomatic. **Zoonotic but no human disease from this strain**. Philippines primarily.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology, PCR, virus isolation
diseases.controlPrevention: Biosecurity, avoid importation from affected areas
diseases.treatment: None needed (asymptomatic)

diseases.name: Encephalomyocarditis (EMCV)
diseases.transmission: Rat urine/feces contamination of feed/water. Can survive in environment
diseases.description: Picornavirus. **Rats are main reservoir**. Three forms: myocarditis (sudden death), reproductive failure, subclinical (most common). Geographic variation in virulence.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + rat problem. Virus isolation from heart/brain, serology (rising titers), PCR, histopathology (myocarditis)
diseases.controlPrevention: RODENT CONTROL critical. Prevent rat access to feed/water. Rodent-proof facilities
diseases.treatment: No treatment. Vaccine available in some countries (efficacy variable)

diseases.name: Enteroviruses (Swine enterovirus)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral transmission, widespread in pig populations
diseases.description: Multiple enterovirus serotypes. Usually subclinical. Occasionally associated with reproductive failure, stillbirths. Clinical significance uncertain.
diseases.diagnosis: Rarely diagnosed specifically. Virus isolation, PCR
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene. Generally not controlled specifically
diseases.treatment: Not applicable (mostly subclinical)

diseases.name: Foot-and-mouth disease (FMD)
diseases.transmission: Extremely contagious: aerosol (documented 60km overwater), direct contact, fomites, contaminated meat/milk. Virus stable in environment
diseases.description: **Most contagious livestock disease**. Aphthovirus. 7 serotypes (O, A, C, SAT1-3, Asia1), >60 strains. **OIE notifiable**. Devastating economic impact. **Vesicular** - clinically indistinguishable from SVD, VES, VS.
diseases.diagnosis: **IMMEDIATELY notify authorities - stop all movement**. Clinical signs (vesicles). Lab: PCR, virus isolation, antigen ELISA, sequencing (strain). **MUST differentiate from SVD/VES/VS** - emergency labs only
diseases.controlPrevention: FMD-free countries: strict import controls, ban swill, rapid response, zoning. Endemic: vaccination (killed vaccines, strain-specific). Biosecurity, movement controls
diseases.treatment: NO TREATMENT. **Stamp out in free countries** (slaughter, carcass disposal, C&D, movement ban). Vaccination + strict controls in endemic regions

diseases.name: Hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis (HEV, VWD)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, oro-nasal. Present in most herds, clinical disease sporadic
diseases.description: Coronavirus. **Only affects pigs <4 weeks old**. Vomiting and wasting disease. Often self-limiting. Present in many herds subclinically.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (vomiting in young piglets), virus detection by IHC/PCR on brain
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene, reduce stress. Exposure of gilts before farrowing may provide immunity
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment, supportive care (tube feeding), electrolytes

diseases.name: Hepatitis E (HEV)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral in pigs. **Humans: undercooked pork (liver), direct contact with pigs**
diseases.description: Hepeviruses. **Zoonotic - major human concern**. Pigs subclinical reservoir. Human infection from undercooked pork, direct contact. Genotype 3 most common.
diseases.diagnosis: PCR on feces, liver. Serology (antibodies common). Usually research only
diseases.controlPrevention: **ZOONOTIC CONTROL**: proper cooking of pork (especially liver), hygiene for pig workers, no specific swine control
diseases.treatment: Not applicable (asymptomatic in pigs)

diseases.name: Influenza (Swine influenza, SIV)
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious aerosol, direct contact. Introduced by humans, birds. Rapid spread within barn
diseases.description: Orthomyxovirus. Subtypes H1N1, H1N2, H3N2 predominate. **Zoonotic - pandemic potential**. Rapid spread within herd (2-3 days). Reassortment with human/avian strains possible. Seasonal pattern (winter).
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (sudden, entire herd). PCR on nasal swabs/lung, virus isolation, serology (paired samples). Subtyping important for epidemiology
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (autogenous or commercial, limited cross-protection). Biosecurity: minimize human movement during human flu season, bird exclusion. All-in/all-out
diseases.treatment: Supportive care (most recover in 5-7 days). Antibiotics for secondary bacterial pneumonia. NSAIDs for fever. Maintain environment, reduce stress

diseases.name: Japanese B Encephalitis (JEV)
diseases.transmission: Culex mosquito vectors (mainly). Pigs amplify virus. Birds reservoir. **Humans from mosquitoes**
diseases.description: **Mosquito-borne** flavivirus. Endemic in South/Southeast Asia. Pigs amplifying hosts. **Zoonotic - major human pathogen**. Stillbirths/abortion storms in naive herds. Outdoor pigs most at risk.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs in endemic areas (summer abortion storms). Serology, virus isolation from fetuses/brain, PCR, IHC
diseases.controlPrevention: Vaccination (inactivated vaccines) in endemic areas before breeding. Mosquito control (difficult). Indoor housing. **Human vaccination available**
diseases.treatment: No treatment. Focus on prevention through vaccination

diseases.name: Nipah virus
diseases.transmission: Fruit bat urine/feces contamination. Pig-to-pig transmission. **Pig-to-human very efficient**, human-to-human possible
diseases.description: Paramyxovirus. **Highly zoonotic** - severe/fatal human disease. Fruit bats (Pteropus) reservoir. Endemic Malaysia, Bangladesh. Pigs developed respiratory disease. **Public health emergency when occurred**.
diseases.diagnosis: **Biosafety level 4 agent**. Serology, PCR, virus isolation (specialized labs only). Report immediately if suspected
diseases.controlPrevention: **CRITICAL BIOSECURITY**. Prevent bat access to pig farms. Stamping out if detected. **Major human health threat**. Worker PPE essential
diseases.treatment: **Cull affected herds**. No treatment. **Human post-exposure prophylaxis** under investigation

diseases.name: Parainfluenza
diseases.transmission: Aerosol transmission suspected
diseases.description: Porcine parainfluenza virus (PPIV). Novel agent, clinical significance still being determined. Associated with mild respiratory disease.
diseases.diagnosis: PCR available in research settings. Role in disease still being investigated
diseases.controlPrevention: Standard respiratory disease control (ventilation, vaccination against other pathogens)
diseases.treatment: Supportive care, control secondary infections

diseases.name: Porcine circovirosis (PCV2, PCVAD)
diseases.transmission: Ubiquitous (present in most herds). Fecal-oral, intrauterine, semen. PCV2 found in many healthy pigs - clinical disease requires cofactors (immune stimulation)
diseases.description: PCV2 (8 genotypes, PCV2b/d most pathogenic). **Major economic disease globally**. Causes PCVAD (wasting), PDNS (dermatitis-nephropathy), reproductive failure. Immunosuppressive. Vaccination highly effective.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (wasting from weaning). PCR on tissues (high viral load diagnostic). IHC on lymphoid tissues. Histopathology: lymphocyte depletion
diseases.controlPrevention: VACCINATION highly effective (dramatic impact since introduction). Reduce stressors, avoid unnecessary vaccines at weaning. Control coinfections
diseases.treatment: No antiviral. Supportive care. Antibiotics for secondary infections. **Prevention through vaccination most important control**

diseases.name: Porcine cytomegalovirus (PCMV)
diseases.transmission: Vertical transmission, nasal secretions, widespread
diseases.description: Betaherpesvirus. Very common, usually subclinical. Occasionally causes rhinitis with sneezing in young pigs. Low economic significance.
diseases.diagnosis: Rarely diagnosed specifically. Serology shows high prevalence. Virus isolation, PCR
diseases.controlPrevention: Not usually controlled specifically. Standard hygiene
diseases.treatment: Not necessary (benign)

diseases.name: Porcine Epidemic Diarrhea (PED, PEDV)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, contaminated feed/ingredients (major concern), fomites, aerosol (short distance). Survives cold
diseases.description: Alphacoronavirus. **Devastating in naive herds**. Mortality up to 100% in <2 week piglets. Very similar to TGE. **Feed contamination major route globally** (spray-dried plasma suspected in US 2013 outbreak). Re-emergence concern.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (sudden, severe diarrhea, high mortality in suckling). PCR on feces/small intestine. Differentiate from TGE (clinical/PCR)
diseases.controlPrevention: STRICT feed biosecurity. Controlled exposure (feedback) in endemic situations. Biosecurity. No consistently effective vaccine. Isolate farrowing groups
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment. Supportive care (warmth, fluids limited). Isowean piglets from immune sows. Controlled exposure of sow herd (feedback) to develop immunity

diseases.name: Porcine parvovirus (PPV)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, venereal, vertical. Ubiquitous in pig populations. Very stable in environment
diseases.description: Parvoviruses (PPV1 most important). **Leading infectious cause of reproductive failure** in naive gilts. Widespread. Very stable virus (survives years in environment). Fetal infection depends on stage of gestation.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (mummies in gilts). Fetal IHC, PCR on mummified fetuses. Serology (gilt immunity status)
diseases.controlPrevention: Gilt vaccination before breeding (MLV or inactivated). Ensure gilt exposure before mating (natural or vaccine). Vaccinate breeding herd. Do NOT introduce naive gilts
diseases.treatment: No treatment. Prevention through vaccination CRITICAL. Ensure gilt immunity before breeding

diseases.name: Porcine Respiratory Coronavirus (PRCV)
diseases.transmission: Aerosol, very contagious
diseases.description: Deletion mutant of TGE virus (respiratory tropism only). Usually subclinical respiratory infection. May provide cross-protection against TGE. Low pathogenicity.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology (TGE/PRCV differentiation difficult). PCR. Clinical disease rare
diseases.controlPrevention: No specific control. Possible protective effect against TGE
diseases.treatment: Not necessary (benign)

diseases.name: Rabies
diseases.transmission: Bite from rabid wildlife (fox, raccoon, skunk, bat). Virus in saliva
diseases.description: **Zoonotic - fatal if untreated**. Lyssavirus. Rare in pigs. Transmitted by wildlife bite. Progressive neurological disease always fatal. **Human exposure = medical emergency**.
diseases.diagnosis: **Do NOT perform necropsy - human exposure risk**. Report to authorities. Laboratory: direct FA test on brain (Negri bodies), PCR
diseases.controlPrevention: **Critical**: wildlife vaccination/control. Report wildlife bites immediately. **Human post-exposure prophylaxis** if bitten by suspected pig
diseases.treatment: **NONE - euthanize animal**. **Human: immediate wound wash + post-exposure prophylaxis (vaccine + immunoglobulin)**

diseases.name: Rotavirus
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, very stable virus, survives in environment. Transmitted sow to piglets
diseases.description: Group A, B, C rotaviruses. Common cause of diarrhea in 1-4 week piglets and first 2 weeks post-weaning. Usually milder than coronavirus diarrheas. Villous atrophy.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + age. Fecal antigen ELISA, PCR, EM of feces. Histopathology: villous atrophy
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene, ensure colostrum. Difficult to prevent (ubiquitous). Vaccines limited efficacy
diseases.treatment: Supportive care (fluids, electrolytes), maintain nutrition. Antibiotics for secondary infections

diseases.name: Senecavirus A (SVA)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, direct contact, fomites. Rodents possible. Survives in environment
diseases.description: Picornavirus causing **vesicular disease** (blisters) clinically identical to FMD/SVD/VES. Also causes transient high mortality in neonatal piglets. Emerged 2002, spreading globally. **OIE-listed**.
diseases.diagnosis: **Report vesicular disease immediately**. Lab: PCR, virus isolation, sequencing. **MUST rule out FMD, SVD, VES, VS**
diseases.controlPrevention: Biosecurity, rodent control. Quarantine new animals. No vaccine available
diseases.treatment: No treatment. Stamping out NOT required (unlike FMD) but significant losses. Supportive care

diseases.name: Swine pox
diseases.transmission: LICE (H. suis) mechanical vector. Direct contact. Survives in scabs
diseases.description: Suipoxvirus. **Lice (Haematopinus suis) are vector** - disease rare where lice controlled. Benign course. Skin lesions heal in 3-4 weeks. Cosmetic more than clinical problem.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (characteristic skin lesions). Histopathology: intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Rule out other vesicular diseases
diseases.controlPrevention: LICE CONTROL (insecticides). Hygiene
diseases.treatment: Usually unnecessary (self-limiting). Lice treatment to prevent spread. Antiseptic if secondary infection

diseases.name: Swine Vesicular Disease (SVD)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral (different from FMD - more intestinal). Direct contact. Contaminated garbage/swill. Survive in environment
diseases.description: Enterovirus causing vesicular disease **clinically indistinguishable from FMD**. Lower mortality than FMD. Endemic in some countries. **OIE-notifiable** due to FMD similarity.
diseases.diagnosis: **Report immediately (FMD rule-out)**. Lab: PCR, virus isolation, antigen ELISA. **Differentiate from FMD, VES, VS, SVA**
diseases.controlPrevention: Ban swill feeding. Import controls. Biosecurity. Stamping out in free countries. Some regions endemic with control programs
diseases.treatment: NO TREATMENT. Stamp out in free countries. Control programs in endemic regions. Less stringent than FMD (lower spread)

diseases.name: Teschen disease (Teschovirus, Talfan)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral, contaminated equipment, subclinical carriers
diseases.description: Enterovirus 1 (virulent) causes Teschen (polioencephalomyelitis, severe CNS). Avirulent strains common, cause Talfan (mild). Virulent strains rare now. Sporadic paralysis.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (progressive paralysis). Virus isolation, PCR on CNS tissue, feces. Serology (but many subclinical)
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene, avoid introducing pigs from affected farms. Vaccination in endemic areas (rare now)
diseases.treatment: No treatment for CNS damage. Supportive care. Prevention through sanitation

diseases.name: Torque teno sus virus (TTSuV)
diseases.transmission: Unknown. Widespread, likely fecal-oral
diseases.description: Anellovirus. Very common (80% pigs), usually coinfection. Initially associated with PMWS but role unclear. Clinical significance still uncertain. May be commensal.
diseases.diagnosis: PCR on tissues. High prevalence in healthy pigs makes interpretation difficult
diseases.controlPrevention: No specific control (significance uncertain)
diseases.treatment: Not applicable

diseases.name: Transmissible Gastroenteritis (TGE, TGEV)
diseases.transmission: Highly contagious fecal-oral. Virus survives in cold. Birds (starlings) mechanical vectors. All-in/all-out failure. Very rapid herd spread
diseases.description: Alphacoronavirus. Clinically identical to PED. Very important historically (before PED emergence). 100% mortality <2 week piglets. Can disappear from herds. Milder in endemic herds with immunity.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs identical to PED. PCR, virus isolation, FA test on intestine. Serology (cross-reaction with PRCV complicates)
diseases.controlPrevention: Endemic: controlled exposure (feedback). Naive herds: strict biosecurity, bird control. No effective vaccine. All-in/all-out farrowing
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment. Supportive care. Feedback to develop herd immunity. Virus can be eliminated from herds

diseases.name: Vesicular exanthema (VES)
diseases.transmission: Contaminated swill containing raw fish/marine mammals. Direct contact
diseases.description: Calicivirus. Clinically **identical to FMD/SVD**. Source: contaminated raw fish/marine mammal products in swill. Last US outbreak 1956. **Eradicated** from pigs. **OIE-listed**.
diseases.diagnosis: **Report immediately**. Lab differentiation from FMD/SVD/VS. Now eradicated
diseases.controlPrevention: Swill feeding ban (implemented post-VES). Import controls. Disease extinct in pigs
diseases.treatment: Not applicable (eradicated)

diseases.name: Vesicular stomatitis (VS)
diseases.transmission: Insect vectors (sandflies, black flies, mosquitoes). Direct contact from other species (horses, cattle). Geographic - Americas
diseases.description: Rhabdovirus (Indiana, New Jersey serotypes). Affects horses, cattle, pigs. Pigs rarely affected but **clinically identical to FMD when infected**. **OIE-notifiable**. Vector-borne (insects).
diseases.diagnosis: **Report immediately (FMD differential)**. Lab: PCR, virus isolation. Differentiate from FMD/SVD/VES
diseases.controlPrevention: Vector control difficult. Avoid contact with other livestock. Quarantine affected premises
diseases.treatment: No specific treatment. Self-limiting in 2 weeks. **Must rule out FMD first**

diseases.name: Ascariasis (Ascaris suum)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral. Eggs very resistant (survive years). Environmental contamination. Most common where hygiene suboptimal
diseases.description: **Most significant intestinal parasite** globally. Large roundworm (20-40cm). Causes: 1) Liver damage (migration) - condemnation, 2) Poor growth, 3) Occasional intestinal obstruction. Very resistant eggs (years).
diseases.diagnosis: Fecal flotation (eggs), post-mortem: worms in intestine, liver milk spots. Slaughter monitoring (liver condemnations)
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene critical. Strategic anthelmintic (especially sows before farrowing). Slat floors better than solid. Break lifecycle
diseases.treatment: Anthelmintics: fenbendazole, levamisole, ivermectin, doramectin, pyrantel. In-feed treatment programs. Sow treatment before farrowing

diseases.name: Coccidiosis (Isospora suis)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral. Oocysts in feces contaminate environment. Very resistant. Sporulation in 24 hours
diseases.description: Intracellular protozoan. Affects 5-15 day old piglets. Most common in large litters, good management herds. Watery diarrhea. Refractory to most treatments.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + age. Fecal flotation (oocysts - need fresh warm sample). Scraping of intestinal mucosa
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene (difficult - oocysts resistant). Dry environment. Hot water/steam cleaning. Strategic treatment. Toltrazuril metaphylaxis
diseases.treatment: Toltrazuril (only effective treatment) oral at 3-5 days of age prophylactically. Supportive electrolytes

diseases.name: Cryptosporidiosis (Cryptosporidium parvum, C. suis)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral. Oocysts resistant. Water contamination
diseases.description: Protozoan causing mild diarrhea in young piglets. **Zoonotic potential (C. parvum)**. Usually self-limiting. Part of diarrhea complex.
diseases.diagnosis: Modified acid-fast stain of feces or intestinal scrapings. FA test, PCR
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene, clean water. Difficult to prevent (resistant oocysts)
diseases.treatment: No effective treatment in pigs. Self-limiting. Supportive care

diseases.name: Lice (Haematopinus suis)
diseases.transmission: Direct contact pig-to-pig. Lice spend entire life on host (die quickly off-host)
diseases.description: Hematophagous louse (sucking). Causes irritation, anemia (heavy infestations), poor growth. **Vector for swinepox and possibly Mycoplasma suis**. Easy to control.
diseases.diagnosis: Visual inspection (lice/nits on skin, especially ears, jowl, skin folds). Easily seen
diseases.controlPrevention: Whole-herd treatment with insecticides. Treat new stock on arrival. Repeat treatment (eggs resistant)
diseases.treatment: Insecticides: ivermectin/doramectin (injectable or pour-on), permethrin, phoxim (sprays). Two treatments 10-14 days apart

diseases.name: Mange (Sarcoptes scabiei var. suis)
diseases.transmission: Direct contact (highly contagious). Contaminated facilities (mites survive weeks). Sow-to-piglet. Fomites
diseases.description: **Most economically important external parasite**. Causes intense pruritus, skin lesions, poor growth (15% FCR loss). Hypersensitivity component. Very contagious. Mites survive off-host 2-3 weeks.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (pruritus, crusty ears). Skin scraping (mites difficult to find - negative doesnt rule out). ELISA (herd status). Therapeutic trial
diseases.controlPrevention: Whole-herd treatment essential (treat all pigs including piglets). Ivermectin/doramectin. Strategic sow treatment. Treat new stock. Control wildlife contact
diseases.treatment: Ivermectin or doramectin (injectable - single dose usually sufficient, repeat in 10-14 days for safety). Phoxim spray. Amitraz (pour-on/spray)

diseases.name: Metastrongylosis (Lungworm)
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of earthworms containing larvae. Lifecycle requires earthworm intermediate host
diseases.description: Metastrongylus spp. lungworms. Use earthworm intermediate host. Causes chronic coughing, pneumonia. Mainly outdoor/extensive systems. Indoor pigs rarely affected.
diseases.diagnosis: Post-mortem: white threadlike worms in bronchi. Baermann technique on feces (larvae). Differentiate from EP
diseases.controlPrevention: Indoor housing (breaks cycle - no earthworms). Outdoor: anthelmintics, rotation of paddocks
diseases.treatment: Benzimidazoles (fenbendazole), levamisole, ivermectin in-feed. Continuous or strategic programs

diseases.name: Red stomach worm (Hyostrongylus rubidus)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral. Direct lifecycle. Environmental contamination. Outdoor pigs
diseases.description: Gastric nematode. Causes chronic gastritis, erosions, ulcers. Poor growth. Outdoor pigs primarily. Usually part of mixed nematode infection.
diseases.diagnosis: Fecal flotation (eggs). Post-mortem: reddish worms in stomach mucosa
diseases.controlPrevention: Strategic deworming (especially sows). Pasture rotation. Indoor housing preferred
diseases.treatment: Benzimidazoles, levamisole, ivermectin. In-feed or injectable

diseases.name: Toxoplasmosis (Toxoplasma gondii)
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of oocysts from cat feces (in feed, water, bedding). Tissue cysts in undercooked pork → HUMANS
diseases.description: Intracellular protozoan. **Zoonotic (major human concern - congenital infection, immunocompromised)**. Cats definitive host. Pigs intermediate host. Usually asymptomatic in pigs.
diseases.diagnosis: Serology (IgG - exposure common). Rarely diagnosed clinically. IHC, PCR on tissues
diseases.controlPrevention: **HUMAN PROTECTION**: Cat control on farms. Proper cooking of pork. Hygiene for pregnant women. Feed protection from cats
diseases.treatment: No practical treatment in pigs (tissue cysts persist). **Human prevention through cooking pork thoroughly**

diseases.name: Trichinella (Trichinellosis)
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of infected meat (rats, wildlife, cannibalism, uncooked garbage). **Humans from undercooked pork**
diseases.description: **Zoonotic - serious human disease**. Muscle-encysting nematode. Pigs asymptomatic. Human infection from raw/undercooked pork. Notifiable in many countries. Testing required for export.
diseases.diagnosis: Digestion of diaphragm/tongue muscle + microscopy (larvae). Serology. ELISA on meat juice
diseases.controlPrevention: **Critical**: ban garbage/swill feeding. Rodent control. Prevent cannibalism. No outdoor access to wildlife. **Proper cooking of pork** (71°C)
diseases.treatment: No treatment in pigs. **Human: albendazole/mebendazole + steroids**. Focus on prevention

diseases.name: Trichuriasis (Whipworm, Trichuris suis)
diseases.transmission: Fecal-oral. Eggs very resistant (years). Environmental contamination
diseases.description: Large intestine whipworm. Causes mucoid diarrhea, poor growth. Outdoor and bedded systems. Less common in modern indoor systems.
diseases.diagnosis: Fecal flotation (characteristic football-shaped eggs). Post-mortem: worms embedded in colonic mucosa
diseases.controlPrevention: Hygiene, strategic deworming. Indoor housing on slats reduces
diseases.treatment: Benzimidazoles most effective. Levamisole less effective. In-feed programs

diseases.name: Biotin deficiency
diseases.transmission: Inadequate diet, avidin in raw egg white, antibiotic interference
diseases.description: Rare vitamin deficiency. Causes skin lesions, hoof cracks. Usually adequate in normal diets. May occur with high raw egg white (avidin binds biotin) or certain antibiotics.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs, response to supplementation. Usually diagnosed retrospectively
diseases.controlPrevention: Adequate biotin in diet (usually present). Avoid raw egg whites in feed
diseases.treatment: Biotin supplementation in feed/water. Response in 2-4 weeks

diseases.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diseases.transmission: Insufficient iron intake. No access to soil. Sow milk inadequate (10% of requirement)
diseases.description: **Very common without supplementation**. Piglets born with low iron stores. Sow milk low in iron. Indoor piglets no access to soil iron. Causes severe anemia by 7-10 days. Critical to supplement.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (pale piglets). Blood analysis: low hemoglobin, hypochromic anemia
diseases.controlPrevention: **IRON INJECTION mandatory for indoor piglets**: 150-200mg iron dextran or gleptoferron IM at 1-3 days of age
diseases.treatment: Iron dextran/gleptoferron 200mg IM. Repeat at 2-3 weeks if still pale. Oral supplementation less effective

diseases.name: Mulberry Heart Disease (Vitamin E/Selenium deficiency)
diseases.transmission: Inadequate Vitamin E and/or Selenium in diet. High PUFA diets predispose. Oxidative stress
diseases.description: Deficiency causes myocardial necrosis, vascular damage. Sudden death in rapidly growing pigs. Heart has mulberry appearance (petechiae). Prevented by adequate Vit E/Se in diet.
diseases.diagnosis: Post-mortem: hemorrhages on heart (mulberry heart), pale streaks in skeletal muscle (white muscle disease), hydrothorax/pericardial effusion
diseases.controlPrevention: Adequate Vitamin E (80-100 IU/kg) and Selenium (0.15-0.3 ppm) in diet. Injectable Vit E/Se at high-risk times
diseases.treatment: Injectable Vitamin E/Selenium to clinically affected pigs (often too late). Focus on prevention in feed

diseases.name: Rickets/Osteoporosis (Ca/P/Vit D deficiency)
diseases.transmission: Inadequate Ca/P/Vit D in diet. Wrong Ca:P ratio. Lack of sunlight (Vit D). Phytic acid binding
diseases.description: Inadequate calcium, phosphorus, or vitamin D causes poor bone mineralization. Rickets (growing bones), osteoporosis (adult bones). Causes fractures, lameness, poor growth.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs, bone fractures. Radiology: poor mineralization. Serum alkaline phosphatase elevated. Measure diet Ca/P/Vit D
diseases.controlPrevention: Proper Ca (0.5-0.9%), P (0.4-0.7%), Ca:P ratio (1.2-1.5:1), Vit D (200-1000 IU/kg) in diet. Outdoor access (sunlight)
diseases.treatment: Correct diet. Vitamin D supplementation. Calcium/phosphorus supplementation. Recovery slow (weeks-months)

diseases.name: Aflatoxicosis
diseases.transmission: Contaminated feed (moldy corn, peanut meal). Drought conditions favor production. Storage in warm humid conditions
diseases.description: Mycotoxin from Aspergillus flavus/parasiticus in feed (corn, peanuts) especially during drought. Causes liver damage, immunosuppression, poor growth. Carcinogenic. More toxic to young pigs. Regulatory limits exist.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs + feed analysis (HPLC, ELISA for aflatoxin). Liver lesions (pale, fatty, cirrhotic). Poor response to antibiotics (immunosuppressed)
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed quality control: test high-risk ingredients. Proper storage (dry, cool). Mycotoxin binders in feed (limited efficacy). Discard moldy feed
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed. No specific treatment. Supportive care. Mycotoxin binders may help if low levels. Recovery depends on liver damage extent

diseases.name: Ergotism
diseases.transmission: Ingestion of ergot-contaminated grain (purple-black sclerotia visible)
diseases.description: Claviceps purpurea sclerotia (ergot) in grain (rye, wheat, barley). Alkaloids cause vasoconstriction → gangrene of extremities. Rare in modern feed quality control.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (gangrenous extremities) + feed inspection (ergot sclerotia visible). Feed analysis for ergot alkaloids
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed quality control - reject grain with >0.3% ergot. Visual inspection of grain
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed. No specific treatment. Gangrenous tissues slough. Prevent secondary infection

diseases.name: Fumonisin toxicosis
diseases.transmission: Contaminated corn (especially wet corn, poor storage). Toxin produced in field and storage
diseases.description: **Most acutely toxic mycotoxin in swine**. Fusarium verticillioides/proliferatum in corn. Causes pulmonary edema (fluid in lungs) and sudden death. Pigs uniquely sensitive (other species less affected).
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (sudden death + pulmonary edema). Post-mortem: lungs heavy, wet, hydrothorax. Feed analysis (HPLC for fumonisin B1)
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed quality control (test corn, especially suspect lots). FDA guidance: <20 ppm for swine. Proper corn storage. Dilute contaminated corn
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed immediately. Supportive care (diuretics, corticosteroids). Often too late. Prevention critical

diseases.name: Ionophore toxicity
diseases.transmission: Feed contamination/formulation error. Carryover in feed mill. Incorrect medication
diseases.description: Accidental inclusion of ionophores (monensin, salinomycin, narasin) intended for poultry/cattle. Pigs highly sensitive. Causes muscle degeneration, heart damage. Rare but serious feed mill accidents.
diseases.diagnosis: History of feed change, clinical signs. Feed analysis for ionophore. Post-mortem: skeletal muscle degeneration (white streaks), heart lesions
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed mill quality control. Separate poultry/swine feed production. Flush between batches
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed. Supportive care. Vitamin E/Selenium. No specific antidote. Prognosis guarded

diseases.name: Salt poisoning (Sodium ion toxicosis)
diseases.transmission: Water deprivation followed by sudden access. Excessive salt in feed (mixing error). Brine/salt ingestion. Frozen waterers
diseases.description: **Water deprivation** is key (salt accumulates, then sudden water access → brain swelling). Also from: excessive salt intake, salt in feed error, brine ingestion. CNS signs characteristic.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (CNS + history of water deprivation). Post-mortem: eosinophilic meningoencephalitis (pathognomonic histology). Elevated Na in serum/CSF
diseases.controlPrevention: Ensure constant water access. Monitor waterers (freeze, blockage). Check salt content in feed (<0.5% for water-deprived pigs)
diseases.treatment: Gradual water reintroduction (restrict initially - too much worsens). Sedatives for seizures. Mannitol/corticosteroids to reduce brain edema. Recovery possible if gradual

diseases.name: Vomitoxin/Deoxynivalenol (DON) toxicosis
diseases.transmission: Fusarium-contaminated grain (weather-related - wet conditions at harvest). Common in wheat, corn
diseases.description: DON mycotoxin from Fusarium in grain (wheat, corn, barley). Causes feed refusal at high levels (vomitoxin). Reduced growth, immune suppression. Very common contamination problem.
diseases.diagnosis: Poor feed intake + poor growth. Feed analysis (ELISA, HPLC for DON). FDA advisory: >5 ppm causes problems
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed testing. Blend contaminated grain to dilute. DON binders limited efficacy. Reject high-level grain
diseases.treatment: Remove/dilute contaminated feed. No specific treatment. Recovery with clean feed

diseases.name: Zearalenone toxicosis
diseases.transmission: Fusarium-contaminated corn/grain (wet conditions). Stored grain moisture >15%
diseases.description: Estrogenic mycotoxin from Fusarium in corn. Mimics estrogen → vulval swelling, reproductive failure. Young gilts most sensitive. Often concurrent with other Fusarium toxins (DON).
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (vulval swelling in prepubertal gilts diagnostic). Feed analysis (ELISA for zearalenone). FDA guidance: >3 ppm problematic
diseases.controlPrevention: Feed quality control, test grain. Proper storage (dry). Mycotoxin binders (limited efficacy)
diseases.treatment: Remove contaminated feed. Clinical signs reverse 5-7 days after removal. No specific treatment

diseases.name: Atresia ani
diseases.transmission: Genetic/developmental defect during gestation
diseases.description: Congenital defect - anal opening absent. Rectum ends blindly. Piglet cannot defecate → progressive abdominal distension. Genetic component suspected. Incompatible with life.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical examination - no anal opening. Progressively distended abdomen
diseases.controlPrevention: Genetic selection against (cull sow/boar lineages if recurrent)
diseases.treatment: Euthanasia (surgical correction not practical/successful in pigs)

diseases.name: Congenital Tremor
diseases.transmission: Type A: viral (BVDV, others). Type B: genetic. Myelin deficiency in CNS
diseases.description: Trembling/shaking in newborn piglets. Type A (viral - causes include BVDV exposure in utero). Type B (genetic). Usually resolves with age. Mild cases compatible with survival.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs at birth. Resolution over weeks. Rule out other causes of trembling
diseases.controlPrevention: Type A: avoid viral exposure during pregnancy. Type B: genetic selection
diseases.treatment: Supportive care (assist nursing, warmth). Usually self-limiting. Euthanize severe non-ambulatory

diseases.name: Epitheliogenesis imperfecta
diseases.transmission: Genetic/developmental defect
diseases.description: Congenital absence of skin in patches. Piglets born with raw areas (no epithelium). Variable extent. Usually lethal due to infection, fluid loss. Genetic basis suspected.
diseases.diagnosis: Visible at birth - obvious skin absence
diseases.controlPrevention: Genetic selection (remove sow/boar from breeding)
diseases.treatment: Euthanasia (usually non-viable due to infection/fluid loss)

diseases.name: Frostbite
diseases.transmission: Exposure to freezing temperatures. Inadequate heating. Wet conditions worsen. Neonatal piglets high risk
diseases.description: Tissue freezing in cold weather. Extremities affected (ears, tail, teats, scrotum, feet). Tissue dies and sloughs. Neonates and thin pigs most susceptible. Preventable.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs. History of cold exposure. Progressive tissue necrosis
diseases.controlPrevention: Adequate heating in farrowing/nursery. Protect piglets. Dry bedding. Draft control
diseases.treatment: Warm affected areas gradually. Prevent secondary infection. Necrotic tissue sloughs. Usually cosmetic damage only

diseases.name: Gastric ulcers
diseases.transmission: Finely ground feed, stress, mycotoxins, Helicobacter suis infection, genetics
diseases.description: Erosions/ulcers in pars esophagea (non-glandular stomach). Causes: finely ground feed, stress, Helicobacter suis, mycotoxins. Can perforate → acute hemorrhage and death. Common in intensive production.
diseases.diagnosis: Sudden death + blood in stomach at post-mortem. Chronic: anemia, melena. Endoscopy (rare). Slaughter inspection
diseases.controlPrevention: Coarser feed particle size. Add fiber/roughage. Reduce stress. Control mycotoxins. Some use gastroprotectants
diseases.treatment: Acute hemorrhage: usually fatal. Chronic: coarsen feed, gastroprotectants (limited data), antibiotics for H. suis

diseases.name: Hemorrhagic Bowel Syndrome (HBS)
diseases.transmission: Unknown. C. difficile toxins suspected. Whey feeding associated in some cases. Proliferation of anaerobes
diseases.description: Acute sudden death in growing pigs with blood-filled intestines. Etiology unknown (Clostridium difficile suspected). Intestinal obstruction from blood clots. Sporadic cases. Increasing recognition.
diseases.diagnosis: Post-mortem: small intestine filled with blood and clots. Intestinal necrosis. No other lesions. Rule out hemorrhagic ileitis
diseases.controlPrevention: Unknown (etiology unclear). Avoid sudden diet changes. Reduce stress
diseases.treatment: None (usually sudden death). Metronidazole may help if C. difficile involved

diseases.name: Hernias (Umbilical, Inguinal, Scrotal)
diseases.transmission: Genetic predisposition (especially scrotal/inguinal). Trauma (umbilical)
diseases.description: Umbilical: failure of umbilical ring closure. Inguinal/scrotal: intestine through inguinal canal (genetic in some lines). Can strangulate. Variable severity. Genetic predisposition strong.
diseases.diagnosis: Visual/palpable swelling. Reducibility indicates viability
