diseases.controlPrevention: Genetic selection against (cull sires/dams of affected). Early identification
diseases.treatment: Small umbilical: may resolve spontaneously. Large/inguinal: surgical repair or cull. Strangulated: emergency surgery (poor prognosis)

diseases.name: Osteochondrosis (OCD)
diseases.transmission: Rapid growth rate, genetic predisposition, Ca/P imbalance, trauma to joint cartilage
diseases.description: Defective endochondral ossification in fast-growing pigs. Cartilage fails to ossify properly → joint lesions. Genetic + nutritional (rapid growth, Ca/P imbalance). Causes lameness, reduced longevity (especially boars/breeding stock).
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical lameness. Radiographs: cartilage lesions. Slaughter: osteochondrosis lesions in joints
diseases.controlPrevention: Moderate growth rates (especially breeding stock). Proper Ca/P nutrition. Genetic selection for soundness. Avoid trauma
diseases.treatment: NSAIDs for pain. Rest. Usually chronic/progressive. Select sound breeding stock

diseases.name: Pityriasis rosea
diseases.transmission: Unknown etiology. Not infectious, not genetic. Possibly immune-mediated
diseases.description: Noncontagious skin condition of unknown cause. Characteristic circular red lesions ("ringworm-like"). Self-limiting in 6-8 weeks. No treatment needed. Cosmetic issue mainly.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical appearance (characteristic lesions). Rule out ringworm (fungal culture negative), mange
diseases.controlPrevention: None (self-limiting, unknown cause)
diseases.treatment: None needed (resolves spontaneously in 6-8 weeks). Cosmetic only

diseases.name: Periweaning Failure to Thrive Syndrome (PFTS)
diseases.transmission: Multifactorial: weaning stress, poor water/feed access, mycotoxins, competition, diseases (subclinical infections)
diseases.description: Multifactorial condition: failure to eat/drink after weaning → progressive wasting and death. Piglets "go back." Causes: weaning stress, mycotoxins, poor water access, bullying, disease.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs: progressive wasting in recently weaned pigs. Rule out specific diseases
diseases.controlPrevention: Optimize weaning management: gradual transition, good water access, low competition, feed accessibility, minimize stress
diseases.treatment: Identify early. Segregate. Assist feeding/watering. Tube feed if needed. Appetite stimulants. Correct underlying causes

diseases.name: Porcine Stress Syndrome (PSS, Malignant Hyperthermia)
diseases.latinName: PSS, Malignant hyperthermia, PSE, Halothane gene
diseases.transmission: GENETIC (halothane gene - autosomal recessive). Stress triggers. Anesthesia (halothane) triggers in carriers
diseases.description: **Halothane gene (RYR1 mutation)**. Causes malignant hyperthermia under stress/anesthesia → sudden death. Also produces PSE meat (pale, soft, exudative - quality defect). Genetic test available. Selection reduced frequency.
diseases.diagnosis: Genetic test (DNA for RYR1 mutation). Halothane challenge test (risky). PSE meat at slaughter
diseases.controlPrevention: GENETIC TESTING and elimination. Avoid stress (gentle handling, cool transport). Do NOT use halothane anesthesia
diseases.treatment: Emergency: cool rapidly (water spray), sedation. Usually fatal if full reaction. Prevention through genetic selection

diseases.name: Rectal Prolapse
diseases.transmission: Predisposing: diarrhea, chronic coughing (respiratory disease), genetic (straight tail), high fiber, mycotoxins. Straining precipitates
diseases.description: Rectum protrudes through anus. Multifactorial: diarrhea, coughing (respiratory disease), genetics (tail shape), mycotoxins. Can lead to cannibalism/septicemia if not addressed.
diseases.diagnosis: Visual - rectum obviously prolapsed
diseases.controlPrevention: Address underlying causes (control diarrhea, respiratory disease). Reduce fiber slightly. Genetic selection
diseases.treatment: Recent prolapse: manual reduction + purse-string suture or rectal pin. Chronic/necrotic: euthanize or cull. Prevent cannibalism (isolate)

diseases.name: Rectal Stricture
diseases.transmission: Post-rectal prolapse complication. Healing with scar tissue formation. Traumatic damage
diseases.description: Narrowing of rectal lumen. Usually sequel to rectal prolapse repair/damage. Feces cannot pass → progressive bloating. Eventually fatal without intervention.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (bloating, difficult defecation), rectal palpation (narrowing)
diseases.controlPrevention: Prevent by proper prolapse management. Early identification
diseases.treatment: Manual dilation (temporary). Surgical correction not practical. Usually cull/euthanize

diseases.name: Shoulder Ulcers (Pressure Sores)
diseases.transmission: Pressure necrosis from lying on hard surfaces. Low body condition (thin sows). Poor gestation feeding
diseases.description: Decubital ulcers on shoulders of thin sows (low body condition). Pressure necrosis from lying on hard floors. Welfare concern. Reflects poor body condition/management.
diseases.diagnosis: Visual examination of shoulders. Body condition scoring (thin sows)
diseases.controlPrevention: Adequate gestation nutrition (maintain body condition). Provide bedding. Identify thin sows early
diseases.treatment: Topical wound care. Antibiotics if infected. Improve nutrition. Provide softer lying area. Prevention critical

diseases.name: Splay Leg (Myofibrillar Hypoplasia)
diseases.transmission: Myofibrillar hypoplasia (muscle underdevelopment). Genetic + environmental (slippery surfaces, large piglets)
diseases.description: Legs splay laterally - piglet cannot stand. Underdevelopment of muscle fibers (especially hind limbs). Genetic + environmental (slippery floors). Variable severity. Taping can help mild cases.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical appearance at birth (characteristic posture)
diseases.controlPrevention: Genetic selection. Provide traction (mats) in farrowing crates. Avoid slippery floors
diseases.treatment: Mild cases: tape legs together (hobbles) for 2-3 days - many recover. Severe cases: euthanize (poor prognosis). Assist nursing

diseases.name: Sunburn
diseases.transmission: UV radiation exposure. White breeds most susceptible. Outdoor housing without shade
diseases.description: UV damage to unpigmented skin. White/pink pigs most susceptible. Outdoor systems. Acute: painful erythema. Chronic: skin cancer risk. Welfare concern.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (sunburned skin). History of sun exposure. White pigs
diseases.controlPrevention: Provide shade (critical). Outdoor systems: trees, shelters. Consider pigmented breeds. Sunscreen impractical. Avoid midday sun
diseases.treatment: Remove from sun immediately. Cool water spray. Topical care (aloe, antiseptic). NSAIDs for pain. Antibiotics if infected. Prevention critical

diseases.name: Thrombocytopenic Purpura (Neonatal Isoerythrolysis analog)
diseases.transmission: Maternal antibodies against piglet platelets (similar to neonatal isoerythrolysis). Previous sensitization
diseases.description: Maternal anti-platelet antibodies destroy piglet platelets. Occurs 7-21 days (after colostral antibody absorption). Causes bleeding disorder. Multiple piglets in litter affected. Rare.
diseases.diagnosis: Clinical signs (bleeding, age 7-21 days), low platelet count, prolonged bleeding time
diseases.controlPrevention: Avoid re-breeding sow-boar combination that produced affected litter
diseases.treatment: Supportive care. Blood transfusion (rarely practical). Prevent trauma. Most severe cases die

diseases.name: Torsion of stomach/intestines
diseases.transmission: Unknown exact cause. Risk factors: genetic, feeding pattern (gorging), gastric bloat, activity after feeding
diseases.description: Sudden twisting of stomach or intestines → strangulation. Causes acute death. Risk factors: genetics, feeding (bloat), activity level. Most common in sows and growers. Rare but consistently present.
diseases.diagnosis: Usually post-mortem diagnosis (sudden death). Necropsy: twisted stomach/intestine, necrosis, hemorrhage
diseases.controlPrevention: Unknown (sporadic). Possibly: feeding management (prevent gorging), genetic selection
diseases.treatment: Usually fatal before found. Emergency surgery not practical. Euthanize if found moribund

diseases.name: Uterine Prolapse
diseases.transmission: Post-farrowing. Large litters, dystocia, hypocalcemia, excessive straining, genetic predisposition
diseases.description: Uterus inverts and protrudes through vulva post-farrowing. Causes: large litters, dystocia, hypocalcemia, uterine atony. Emergency condition. Can be fatal (hemorrhage, shock).
diseases.diagnosis: Visual - uterus obviously prolapsed post-farrowing
diseases.controlPrevention: Prevent dystocia (farrowing supervision). Calcium supplementation. Early identification
diseases.treatment: EMERGENCY: manual replacement under epidural anesthesia. Oxytocin after replacement. Purse-string suture to prevent recurrence. Antibiotics, NSAIDs. Prognosis guarded. Usually cull sow

diseases.name: Vaginal/Cervical Prolapse
diseases.transmission: Late gestation. Genetics, obesity, high intra-abdominal pressure, constipation
diseases.description: Vaginal/cervical tissue protrudes through vulva (usually late gestation). Less severe than uterine prolapse. Causes: genetics, obesity, high fiber diet, constipation. Can progress to uterine prolapse at farrowing.
diseases.diagnosis: Visual examination - tissue protruding from vulva pre-farrowing
diseases.controlPrevention: Genetic selection against. Avoid obesity. Prevent constipation (fiber management)
diseases.treatment: Manual replacement. Purse-string suture if recurs. Monitor at farrowing (risk of uterine prolapse). Usually cull sow after weaning
